item.title: Python Regex
item.description: Python Regex In Python, there is a tool to locate certain characters, and be able to edit them. This can be useful in data science applications- for example, to edit different ways to spelling a word to be standardized.

item.title: Projects
item.description: Projects Here are some projects I have been working on: Project 1 Project 2

###Project 1, Lydia McDonald, Lgm887 library(dplyr) library(tidyverse) library(ggplot2) Airquality <- read.delim("~/Airquality.txt") Temperature <- read.delim("~/Temperature.txt") head(Airquality) ## Date Ozone SulfurDioxide NitrogenDioxide PM2.5 ## 1 1/1/2018 29 NA 3.0 1.1 ## 2 1/2/2018 25 0.3 5.8 2.1 ## 3 1/3/2018 24 0.0 4.5 0.9 ## 4 1/4/2018 28 0.6 14.4 2.3 ## 5 1/5/2018 33 0.6 10.9 3.9 ## 6 1/6/2018 37 0.5 10.3 8.9 head(Temperature) ## Date Temp ## 1 1/1/2018 26.

item.title: Project2
item.description: library(tidyverse) ## -- Attaching packages ----------------------------------------------------------- tidyverse 1.2.1 -- ## v ggplot2 3.2.1 v purrr 0.3.3 ## v tibble 2.1.3 v dplyr 0.8.3 ## v tidyr 1.0.0 v stringr 1.4.0 ## v readr 1.3.1 v forcats 0.4.0 ## -- Conflicts -------------------------------------------------------------- tidyverse_conflicts() -- ## x dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter() ## x dplyr::lag() masks stats::lag() Airquality <- read.csv("~/Airquality2.csv") Airquality2<- Airquality %>% mutate(OzoneLevel = ifelse(Ozone>mean(Ozone),1,0)) head(Airquality2) ## Date Ozone SulfurDioxide NitrogenDioxide PM2.5 Temp Month OzoneLevel ## 1 1/1/2018 29 NA 3.
